Reviews.Content: Great Find in Dallas After our stay in San Antonio, we drove back to Dallas on our way to Tennessee. We found this motel in a Texas coupon book at one of the welcome centers, which, by the way, aren't very sanitary. It advertised $40 a night, cheaper than our previous nights in Dallas. This motel was very clean and had great resources like telephone books, advertisements, and menus to local restaurants. The continental breakfast that morning was fine, it had a make-your-own-waffle machine, but the juice dispenser was not in working order. The coupon said it had laundry services, but there were no facilities onsite. We felt safe in the area, and were located next to a car dealership. If you do decide to venture out into the surroundings, make sure you have a trusty map. My advice would to travel by interstate as much as possible, since it is very unlikely you would get lost. I reccommend this motel to anyone visitng Dallas for a night or two, and make sure you grab a coupon book, because it will save you alot.

Reviews.Content: Hotel Stay Filled with Problems The purpose of this e-mail is to complain about the Best Western Executive Inn in Dallas. You know your T.V. commercial where the black SUV's pull up outside a hotel  allegedly check it out before representing it? Well you guys must have driven PAST this one. I purposely picked this hotel because it stated, in it's description, that it had had a recent million dollar renovation. I checked in Friday 6/30, exhausted, and immediately took a nap then ran out to an appt., so I didn't immediately complain about the dumpiness of the room (torn curtains, stained carpet  furniture). I was out all day 7/1 and when I came back @ 11:20 pm, my card key didn't work. When I went to the front desk, (first to ask what their definition of recent renovation was) the clerk kept telling me that no one was in that room because the room was about to be renovated. It was too late at night to move, so we agreed that I would move the next morning and be credited 6/30  7/1, due to their mistake. This hotel is run by a family of either Pakistani's or Indian's, and they don't seem to communicate with each other. They also don't seem to grasp that the definition of Customer Service is follow through, not just lip service. I had to approach them each day for 4 days to see if they notified you of my 2 night credit. (I finally had you call them to get my credit applied.) That was because I had to keep going to the front desk to have my card key reactivated. They told me that the card key de-activates if I pass by something electronic like a T.V. or a security system? What kind of nonsense is that??? Once I'm moved, I inquire about future incoming calls, since I have given out my old room # to several people including family members, that I was expecting to hear back from. I'm told that they put a do not disturb on my old room # and when the call kicks back, they will transfer it to my new room/v-mail. Needless to say, that never happened. Almost every night when I came in, there were no messages (either v-mail or at the front desk) and the next day I would see people who said they tried calling me hourly the day before and either got no answer at the hotel front desk or, when rarely answered, were told that my phone was busy! I was out every day from 9 am to 10 pm and my callers knew it, and yet the clerks at the front desk insisted that my phone was busy, never took any messages if they answered their phone at all! Their habit of not answering the phone apparently happened as far back as the Monday before my arrival when I called them to verify the amenities I had requested. I also had Hotels.com call them, with no answer, and had Best Western call them also with no answer. They were then sent some kind of intercompany electronic message with instructions to call me...and surprise, that never happened either. Like I said, very poor follow through!!!  This was my first experience with Hotels.com and it was definitely not a positive one.
Reviews.Author: VeryParticular
